multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Dermatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Ask different questions to cover more information. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I have red, bump-like patches around my mouth, chin, and between my eyebrows that are tender and feel like they're stinging and burning.
How long have you been experiencing these symptoms?
I've been experiencing these symptoms on and off for two years.
Have you noticed any triggers that might cause these symptoms to flare up, such as certain foods, weather conditions, or stress?
Yes, using exfoliating facial washes seems to aggravate my symptoms.
Do you have any known skin conditions or allergies?
No, I don't have any known skin conditions or allergies.
Have you used any new skincare products or medications before these symptoms started?
No, I haven't used any new skincare products or medications before these symptoms started.
Do these patches ever have fluid-filled blisters or only remain as red, inflamed bumps?
The patches remain as red, inflamed bumps.
Final Diagnosis: Perioral dermatitis.

My symptoms include red, raised patches with some pustules around my mouth, chin, and between the eyebrows. These patches are tender, and they sting and burn.

The symptoms started two years ago.

They flare up periodically.

Yes, I've used topical antibiotics, azelaic acid cream, retinoid agents, benzoyl peroxide preparations, topical corticosteroids, and oral tetracycline.

Previously, these treatments were successful in completely resolving each outbreak, but currently, the lesions are persisting despite treatment.

No, I haven't been diagnosed with any other chronic skin conditions and do not have a family history of skin issues.
Final Diagnosis: Perioral dermatitis.
